column3: Household-level Food Insecurity Rates (3 year average)
column4: Household Food Security in the United States.  U.S. Department of Agriculture, Economic Research Service.
column6: Year figures represent middle year of three-year average, 2012 data not yet available.  See State-Level Prevalence of Food Insecurity.

column3: Marginal Food Insecurity (individual level,  3-year moving average)
column4: Current Population Survey, December Supplement
column5: Rates were generated using NBER December CPS Supplement Files
column6: Marginally food insecure if household answers "yes" to 1 or more questions from the Core Food Security Model, Current Population Survey.  Figures are 3-year moving averages.

column3: Food Insecurity (individual level,  3-year moving average)
column4: Current Population Survey, December Supplement
column5: Rates were generated using NBER December CPS Supplement Files
column6: Food insecure if household answers "yes" to 3 or more questions,  from the Core Food Security Model, Current Population Survey.  Figures are 3-year moving averages.

column3: Very Low Food Security  (individual level,  3-year moving agerage)
column4: Current Population Survey, December Supplement
column5: Rates were generated using NBER December CPS Supplement Files
column6: Very low food secure if household with children answers "yes" to 8 more questions , or household without children answers "yes" to more than 6 questions from the Core Food Security Model, Current Population Survey.  Figures are 3-year moving averages.

column3: Gross State Product
column4: State Economic Growth.  U.S. Department of Commerce, Bureau of Economic Analysis
column6: Variable is denoted Gross Domestic Product, by State (all industry total).  Figures measured in millions of current dollars.  1997-2010 data updated to reflect most recent estimates.

column3: Percent of Low Income Uninsured Children
column4: Number of Low Income Uninsured Children under 19 by State (at or below 200% of Poverty).  U.S. Census Bureau, Housing and Household Economic Statistics Division.
column6: Poverty figures are three-year averages (in thousands).  Year figures represent middle year of three-year averages.

column3: Total number of participants of Aid to Families with Dependent Children/Temporary Assistance to Needy Families (AFDC)

column4: Food Stamp Program: Average Monthly Participation by Number of Households. U.S. Department of Agriculture, Food and Nutrition Service.

column3: AFDC/TANF Maximum Monthly Benefit for 2-person family.
column4: Congressional Research Service (CRS) with data from the Urban Institute's "Welfare Rules Database."
column6: 2006 to 2010 state TANF benefit data come from the Urban Institute Welfare Rules Database.  In few instances, database values for the monthly benefit for a family of 3 found at fas.org do not match those from Table L5 in the WRD.  When this occurs, we calculate the growth rate for 3-person family monthly benefits derived from 2010's Table L5 to 2011's Table L5. This growth rate is then applied to 2- and 4-person families.

column3: AFDC/TANF Maximum Monthly Benefit for 3-person family.
column4: Urban Institute Welfare Rules Database: TANF Maximum Monthly Benefit for 3-person family.
column6: 2006 to 2010 state TANF benefit data come from the Urban Institute Welfare Rules Database.  In few instances, database dollar amount values do not match those from Table L5 in the WRD.  When this occurs, we apply a growth rate between the database value and the corresponding amount for the previous year's L5 table for 3-person families.  This growth rate is then applied to 2- and 4-person families.

column3: AFDC/TANF Maximum Monthly Benefit for 4-person family.
column4: Congressional Research Service (CRS) with data from the Urban Institute's "Welfare Rules Database."
column6: 2006 to 2010 state TANF benefit data come from the Urban Institute Welfare Rules Database.  In few instances, database values for the monthly benefit for a family of 3 found at fas.org do not match those from Table L5 in the WRD.  When this occurs, we calculate the growth rate for 3-person family monthly benefits derived from 2010's Table L5 to 2011's Table L5. This growth rate is then applied to 2- and 4-person families.

column3: State SSI supplements for individuals living independently
column4: State Assistance Programs for SSI Recipients (January 2007) - Optional State Supplementation Payment Levels.  Social Security Administration, Office of Policy & Office of Research, Evaluation, and Statistics.
column6: Update expected on socialsecurity.gov in November 2013. 2009 Payment levels are for January 2009 under "state supplementation living independently" category.  Illinois supplementation based on individual assessment.  Massachusetts, Nevada provide variety of state supplements based on type of SSI qualification.

column3: Maximum amount payable to an SSI recipient in combined Federal and State supplementary payments

column6: This value combines federal and state SSI benefit payments.

column3: combined montlhy maximum potential SSI and food stamp benefits for aged individuals living independently

column6: This value combines total SSI benefits and 1-person food stamp benefits. 2008 not updated.

column1: anyapp = fraction of year any welfare waiver was approved
anyimp = fraction of year any welfare waiver was implemented
ebti = fraction of year EBT program implemented
abawd = 1 if state has waiver from FSP ABAWD requirement
column3: These are dates when welfare waivers and TANF policies were either approved or implemented.  Variations of these were used in Figlio and Ziliak (1999); Ziliak, Gundersen, and Figlio (2003); Ziliak (2007)

column1: aptl = fraction of year time limit on welfare was approved
apex = fraction of year for exemption approval
apsa = fraction of year sanctions approved
apern = fraction of year earnings disregards approved
apcap = fraction of year family cap approved
apwrk = fraction of year work requirements approved
Ellwood = 1 if welfare policies are strict based on David Ellwoods's metric
Meyer = 1 if welfare policites are strict based on Meyer and Rosenbaum's metric
Grogger1-Grogger3 = 1 if welfare policies are strict based on alternative metrics in Grogger and Karoly (2005)
